title: 6 essential oils to use for Ayurvedic aromatherapy in your home
author: Condé Nast; Dr Taruna Yadav
description: Fragrances to set the right mood in your living space
cleaned_text: Fragrances play an important role in establishing the mood of our immediate surroundings. They can uplift your home and bring out its true disposition. [Ayurvedic](https://www.architecturaldigest.in/content/kerala-kairali-ayurvedi-retreat-palakkad-village/) aromatherapy uses the properties of essential oils and their scents to balance the doshas (energetic dispositions according to ayurvedic principles) of your living space and infuse the area with harmony and vitality. Ayurveda divides the clock into cycles based on the type of energy that is predominant in our bodies and in nature during each four-hour window. Every day, we cycle through the three doshas—Vata, Pitta, and Kapha—twice a day, as per the following schedule: Kapha: 6 am to 10 am; 6 pm to 10 pm Pitta: 10 am to 2 am; 10 pm to 2 pm Vata: 2 am to 6 am; 2 pm to 6 pm Using Fragrances to Complement Doshas Each dosha corresponds to a certain type of scent. Here's how to choose the right fragrance for each part of the day. For the Kapha Time Frame Choose fragrances that are warm, slightly spicy, and stimulating such as rosemary, basil, eucalyptus, peppermint, cedar, sage, anise, and ginger. These will also energize you on cold days. For the Pitta Time Frame Use sweet aromas like jasmine, gardenia, rose, mint and chamomile, and yarrow. These essential oils will also soothe you during the extreme summer heat. For the Vata Time Frame Warm, citrusy oils like sandalwood, sweet orange, rose, lemon, jasmine vanilla, lavender, lemongrass, lemon, ginger, and ylang-ylang will work well here. They're pleasant and grounding to the senses. Essential Oils to Use as Aromatherapy in Your Home Lavender Lavender has a sweet, floral scent with a herbal undertone. It relieves anxiety and stress by calming the limbic system. Use it in your bedroom for a restful night's sleep. Peppermint Try using this [essential oil](https://www.architecturaldigest.in/content/type-home-fragrance-guide-tips/) in your workspace. An energy booster, the scent of peppermint invigorates the mind, helps concentration, and stimulates clear thinking. Cinnamon Deliciously associated with baked goods, cinnamon elicits feelings of warmth and comfort. It's a great scent to use in the kitchen. Bergamot This is a good essential oil to use in your living room, where you spend most of your time. The citrus scent helps relieve tension and improve your mood. Citronella Citronella has a rich, crisp lemony aroma. It's a natural insect repellent, making it best suited for your patio or balcony. Lemongrass Lemongrass also has a lemony aroma, though more subtle than citronella, which makes it refreshing and uplifting. It has anti-bacterial, anti-fungal, and anti-microbial properties and is also a natural insect repellent. Use this fragrance in the bathroom. Dr Taruna Yadav is the senior ayurveda expert at Forest Essentials.
